sentences.sentence: “Oh! My dear father,” she cried, “go and write back immediately.
Consider how important every moment is in such a situation as this.”
“Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike taking the trouble to do so yourself.”
“I dislike it very much,” he replied, “but it must be done.”
“And they must marry! And yet he is such a wicked( 缺德的 ) man!”
“Yes, yes, they must marry.
There is nothing else that can be done.
But there are two things that I very much want to know.
One is, how much money has your uncle spent to make this happen? The other is, how am I ever going to repay( 偿还 ) him?”
“Money! My uncle!” cried Jane.
“What do you mean?”
“Wickham is a fool if he marries Lydia for anything less than ten thousand pounds.
I am sorry to think so poorly of him, at the very beginning of our relationship.”
“Ten thousand pounds! Good heavens! How can you repay( 偿还 ) even half as much as that?”
Mr. Bennet made no answer, and each of them, deep in thought, continued silently until they reached the house.
Their father then went to the library to write, and Elizabeth took refuge( 庇护 ) in her own room to think over what had happened.
Poor Lydia’s situation was bad enough, but Elizabeth was thankful that it was no worse.
Though neither rational( 合理的 ) happiness nor prosperity( 荣华富贵 ) could be expected for her sister,
compared with what they had feared for her two hours ago, she felt all the advantages they had gained.
Mr. Bennet had very often wished before that, instead of spending his whole income, he had set aside some money each year for his children.
He now wished this more than ever.
If he had saved money as he should have done, Lydia would not now owe( 亏欠 ) her uncle so greatly for saving whatever part of her reputation( 名声 ) still remained for her to keep.
What’s more, the thought of choosing one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might never have crossed her mind.
At the beginning of Mr. Bennet’s marriage, saving money seemed completely useless, because they were of course going to have a son.
The son would inherit( 继承 ) the family’s property, and would then take care of Mr. Bennet’s younger children after his death.
His wife then gave birth to five daughters in a row, but still a son did not come.
Mrs. Bennet was certain that she would have a son for many years after Lydia’s birth,
and by the time that it was too late to hope for another child, it was then too late also to begin saving money.
It had been agreed when they had married that Mr. Bennet would leave five thousand pounds to be given to Mrs. Bennet and the children after his death.
But it had not yet been decided how this money would be divided.
This point, with regard to Lydia, now had to be settled.
Mr. Bennet did not hesitate( 犹豫 ) to agree to the proposal( 提议 ) being offered to him.
Elizabeth was now genuinely( 真正地 ) sorry that she had told Mr. Darcy about her fears for her sister.
Since Lydia’s marriage would soon bring an end to the crisis( 危机 ), the family might otherwise have been able to keep it a secret from everyone who had not been directly involved.
She was not concerned about whether Mr. Darcy would tell others what had happened.
In fact, there were few people who she would have trusted more to keep such details( 细节 ) a secret.
At the same time, perhaps no outcome( 结局 ) could be more humiliating( 丢脸的 ) to her than that Mr. Darcy himself now knew about her family’s disgrace( 耻辱 ).
It seemed impossible that they could ever see each other again, at least on the same terms.
Even if Lydia had married under more honorable circumstances( 境遇 ), it still would seem unlikely that Mr. Darcy would want to associate himself with her family,
since they were now connected with a man whom he so rightly looked down upon.
She began now to understand that Darcy was exactly the man who would most suit her.
Although his disposition( 性情 ) was different to her own, he would have satisfied all her desires.
But such a happy marriage was now completely impossible, and her family was soon to form a connection of a very different kind.
How little permanent( 长久的 ) happiness there could be for a couple who were drawn together only because their passions( 感情 ) were stronger than their virtue( 美德 ), she could only guess.
Their sister’s wedding( 结婚的 ) day arrived.
The carriage was sent to meet the newly married couple, and they were to return in it by dinnertime( 晚餐时间 ).
The elder Miss Bennets dreaded( 惧怕 ) their arrival, and Jane especially worried about what her sister would soon suffer.
They arrived. Lydia’s voice was heard in the entryway( 入口 ), the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room.
Her mother stepped forward, embraced( 拥抱 ) her, and welcomed her with great enthusiasm.
With an affectionate( 深情的 ) smile to Wickham, who followed his wife, Mrs. Bennet wished them both joy and happiness.
Their greeting from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite so friendly.
If Lydia had felt no embarrassment( 尴尬 ) at first, it could not be assumed( 认为 ) that time would cause any great changes in her attitude.
She wanted greatly to see Mrs. Phillips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbors, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham” by each of them.
In the meantime( 同时 ), she went to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids( 女仆 ) after dinner to show her ring, and to boast( 自吹自擂 ) to them about being married.
Lydia and Wickham would not stay for more than ten days with them.
Before he had left London, Mr. Wickham had been given a new assignment( 任务 ) in the North, and he needed to join his new regiment( 团 ) at the end of two weeks.
No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short.
Wickham’s affection( 感情 ) for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected to find it, that is to say, not equal to Lydia’s for him.
Lydia was exceedingly( 极其地 ) fond of him.
He was her dear Wickham on every occasion, and no one could compete with him in any way.

options.cn: 因为他们相信他们会有一个儿子。
